articles.headline: Netanyahu’s Power Is Extended as Rival Accepts Israel Unity Government
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, an embattled political survivor, persuaded Benny Gantz to join forces with him to combat the coronavirus.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, an embattled political survivor, persuaded Benny Gantz to join forces with him to combat the coronavirus.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and his former challenger, Benny Gantz, agreed Monday night to establish a unity government, a deal that finally breaks a yearlong political impasse and keeps Mr. Netanyahu in office as he faces trial on corruption charges.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: New York Needed Ventilators. So They Developed One in a Month.
articles.snippet: The pandemic inspired an innovative project to design and make a low-cost ventilator in weeks, not years.
articles.abstract: The pandemic inspired an innovative project to design and make a low-cost ventilator in weeks, not years.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is part of our continuing Fast Forward series, which examines technological, economic, social and cultural shifts that happen as businesses evolve.

articles.headline: Excluded From Bailouts, Mortgage Servicers Face Cash Crunch
articles.snippet: Lawmakers and lobbyists warn that missed house payments could leave servicers insolvent but federal officials are not sold on the need for a rescue.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers and lobbyists warn that missed house payments could leave servicers insolvent but federal officials are not sold on the need for a rescue.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal policymakers have rushed to backstop nearly every corner of the financial system as the coronavirus exacts a bruising toll on the U.S. economy. But there is growing concern that a critical corner of the housing industry has been overlooked, putting mortgage companies in a precarious position as millions of borrowers delay payments.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport, Matthew Goldstein and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Too Much Oil: How a Barrel Came to Be Worth Less Than Nothing
articles.snippet: One oil price went negative on Monday, signaling that there is no place to store all the crude the world is producing but not using.
articles.abstract: One oil price went negative on Monday, signaling that there is no place to store all the crude the world is producing but not using.
articles.lead_paragraph: Something bizarre happened in the oil markets on Monday: Prices fell so much that some traders paid buyers to take oil off their hands.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Trump Plans to Suspend Immigration to U.S.
articles.snippet: The president portrayed the measure, his most wide-ranging attempt yet to seal off the country from the world, as a bid to save Americans’ jobs amid the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.abstract: The president portrayed the measure, his most wide-ranging attempt yet to seal off the country from the world, as a bid to save Americans’ jobs amid the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Monday evening that he intended to close the United States to people trying to immigrate into the country to live and work, a drastic move that he said would protect American workers from foreign competition once the nation’s economy began to recover from the shutdown caused by the coronavirus outbreak.
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers, Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

articles.headline: Pandemic’s Costs Stagger the Nursing Home Industry
articles.snippet: Even before the coronavirus swept through care facilities, many were struggling with thin profit margins. Now they could be wiped out.
articles.abstract: Even before the coronavirus swept through care facilities, many were struggling with thin profit margins. Now they could be wiped out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even before they became deadly petri dishes for the worst pandemic in generations, many nursing homes were struggling to stay afloat and provide quality care.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein, Robert Gebeloff and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Spectrum Employees Are Getting Sick Amid Debate Over Working From Home
articles.snippet: More than 230 workers at Charter Communications, the cable and internet giant known as Spectrum, have tested positive for Covid-19, as employees question how many of them must work in the office.
articles.abstract: More than 230 workers at Charter Communications, the cable and internet giant known as Spectrum, have tested positive for Covid-19, as employees question how many of them must work in the office.
articles.lead_paragraph: Employees at Charter Communications, the internet, cable TV and phone giant known as Spectrum, have been getting sick while adhering to a company policy that has required thousands of them to work in offices and call centers rather than from home.
